metadata.titleEn: Zircon Hf isotopic data set of Mesozoic Cenozoic magmatic rocks and Mesozoic Yidun Granitoids in the southern Tibetan Plateau, Lhasa Block (2022)
metadata.description: The dataset mainly includes zircon Hf isotope data of Mesozoic and Cenozoic granitoids and some dykes in the central and western Lhasa massif, southern Tibet. This data is mainly used to study the origin of various magmatic rocks related to Neotethys subduction at the convergent plate margin, and to constrain the subduction process; The study of the genesis of various magmatic rocks during the syn collision between India and Eurasia is of great significance to the study of the net growth of continental crust and the genesis of silicon rich continental crust; The study of the genesis of various post collisional magmatic rocks is of great significance to the discussion of the mechanism of post collisional tectonomagmatism and the crust mantle structure; It is of great significance to study the petrogenesis of volcanic rocks in the collision zone and the origin of temporal and spatial variations of enriched components in magma for using petrological evidence to constrain the time limit of Indo Eurasian collision. In addition, the data set also includes zircon Hf isotope data of late Triassic granitoids from Yidun terrane in the eastern Qinghai Tibet Plateau, which can be used to study the origin of large batholiths at the margin of convergent plates and determine the genetic mechanism of silicon rich continental crust. 60 sets of test samples, excluding repeated sample testing, are tested by MC-ICP-MS, and the testing unit is China University of Geosciences (Beijing). The data comes from published articles, which are true and reliable. It can be applied to the study of magmatic rock genesis.
metadata.instructions:
Zircon Hf isotope data is stored in Excel format. The file name is "Zircon Hf 2022. xlsx", where Zircon Hf represents content and 2022 represents year.
Data reading method: The data can be directly opened in Excel workbook.

Quantification.Question: How many zircon Hf isotope samples were tested using MC-ICP-MS in a dataset related to the magmatic rocks of the southern Tibetan Plateau and Yidun granites?

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the need for using zircon Hf isotopic data to understand the genesis of magmatic rocks in convergent plate boundaries?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The use of zircon Hf isotopic data is necessitated by the need to study the genesis of various magmatic rocks associated with the subduction of the Neo-Tethys Ocean at convergent plate boundaries, to constrain the subduction processes, and to explore the net growth of continental crust and the origin of silica-rich continental crust during the India-Eurasia collision.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential impacts on the understanding of crustal growth and silicic continental crust formation when integrating zircon Hf isotopic data from Mesozoic and Cenozoic igneous rocks?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating zircon Hf isotopic data from Mesozoic and Cenozoic igneous rocks can significantly enhance the understanding of crustal growth and silicic continental crust formation by providing insights into the genesis of magmatic rocks related to subduction processes and the mechanisms of post-collision tectonic magmatism. This data sheds light on the composition and evolution of the crust-mantle structure and helps constrain the timing of India-Eurasia collision events, thereby offering crucial evidence for crustal development and enrichment processes.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What instrumental and procedural methodologies are used to collect zircon Hf isotope data from Mesozoic and Cenozoic igneous rocks in southern Tibet and eastern Tibetan Plateau, and how do these methods ensure the reliability of the isotopic data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The instrumental methodology used to collect zircon Hf isotope data involves MC-ICP-MS (Multi-Collector Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry), conducted by the China University of Geosciences (Beijing). This method is chosen for its precision and accuracy in isotopic analysis. Procedurally, the dataset includes 60 sets of test samples, excluding repeated sample tests, which ensures that the data is reliable and valid for research purposes. The data originates from published articles, adding an additional layer of credibility.
